title: FirstFT: Macron vows to heal divisions after winning second term
text:
Emmanuel Macron defeated his far-right rival Marine Le Pen to be re-elected president of France, vowing to tackle the country's “doubts and divisions” during his second five-year term.

Le Pen conceded shortly after the first projections showed Macron winning more than 58 per cent of yesterday's presidential run-off. The far-right leader said her Rassemblement National party would fight on in elections for France's National Assembly in June.

Speaking to supporters in front of the Eiffel Tower in Paris, Macron acknowledged he would have to preside over a divided nation in his second term after many backed his rival or failed to vote.

“Our country is beset by doubts and divisions,” he said. “Today's vote requires us to consider all the hardships of people's lives and to respond effectively to them and to the anger expressed.”

Victory for Macron, first elected in 2017, comes as a relief to investors and to France's EU and Nato allies in the midst of the Russian invasion of Ukraine. A win for the Eurosceptic Le Pen, who wanted to pull France out of Nato's military command structure, would have been a geopolitical earthquake akin to Brexit or the election of Donald Trump.

However, Le Pen's far-right party had its best showing since the second world war and 28 per cent of voters did not turn out — the highest level of abstention since 1969. More than half of voters in the first round two weeks ago voted for nationalist, Eurosceptic candidates of the extreme right or left.

Read more on the French election

  • Analysis: Macron's convincing victory disguises the reality that the nationalist, Eurosceptic, anti-immigration far-right is stronger than at any time since the second world war.

  • Instant Insight: Emmanuel Macron's strategy paid off handsomely, writes Ben Hall. He was counting on French voters to close ranks against the far-right — the so-called republican front — to prevail once again. But the level of abstentions is hardly a ringing endorsement of Macronism, he says.

  • Gideon Rachman: This is Macron's chance to shape Europe's future, writes the FT's chief foreign affairs commentator.

Did you breath a little easier when you heard Macron had won or did you hope for a Le Pen victory? Send your thoughts to firstft@ft.com. Here's the rest of the day's news — Gordon

The latest from the war in Ukraine

  • The US has pledged to resume diplomatic operations in Ukraine and offered the country more than $322mn in military funding after a stealth trip to Kyiv by secretary of state Antony Blinken and defence secretary Lloyd Austin.

  • Vladimir Putin has lost interest in diplomatic efforts to end his war and instead appears set on seizing as much territory as possible, according to three people briefed on conversations with him.

  • Russian forces have shifted their attention to Donbas, in the east of Ukraine, with many predicting a brutal and bloody onslaught.

  • Putin is pushing Finland and Sweden into Nato, says the FT's editorial board. But Stockholm must reckon with its history of neutrality, adds Richard Milne.

Five more stories in the news

1. Exclusive: Gates-backed company accused of firing whistleblowers who flagged misconduct Ecolab, a US-listed hygiene company backed by Bill Gates, last year praised the “integrity” of an executive who resigned over an alleged compliance breach and later fired two employees who had flagged the misconduct internally, the Financial Times can reveal.

2. Beijing gripped by panic buying as Covid cases rise Beijing residents emptied supermarket shelves of meat and vegetables and non-perishable foods yesterday and today as they brace for a Shanghai-style lockdown. Separately, it has been revealed that one of China's top government health officials has repeatedly promoted Covid-19 remedies included in Beijing's official treatment protocol for the disease without disclosing his links with the manufacturers.

3. Nissan shares fall on reports Renault is considering selling part of its stake Shares in the Japanese carmaker fell more than 4 per cent in Tokyo today on reports that Renault, Nissan's largest shareholder, is considering selling part of its stake. Renault has been pushing ahead with plans to split its EV and combustion engine businesses as it moves to catch up with Tesla and Volkswagen.

4. Norway's wealth fund backs calls for Credit Suisse special audit The world's largest sovereign wealth fund has backed calls for a special audit of the Swiss lender and warned that it would not absolve executives and board members from blame over scandals including the collapses of supply chain finance firm Greensill and family office Archegos Capital.

5. Activist urges investors to move against Just Eat Takeaway's board One of Just Eat Takeaway's largest shareholders has called on other investors to join it in voting against the re-election of the food delivery group's finance chief and most of its supervisory board. Cat Rock Capital said JET's board had overseen a “catastrophic destruction of equity value” since announcing the acquisition of US food delivery group Grubhub in June 2020.

The day ahead

Company earnings Activision Blizzard, which agreed to be bought by Microsoft in January, is expected to report lower first-quarter earnings as the positive effects of the pandemic for video games makers wane. Comments on inflation and the supply chain will be closely followed by investors when Coca-Cola releases first-quarter results.

Amazon labour union vote After Staten Island workers won a milestone battle to organise a union at the ecommerce company, staff at another facility across the street will cast ballots in their own union election.

Economic data Data are expected to show Brazil had a current account deficit of $1.75bn in February, down from $8.1bn the previous month.

Ursula von der Leyen visits New Delhi The EU is preparing to announce the creation of a trade and technology council with India as the European Commission president meets Narendra Modi, the country's prime minister.

What else we're reading

Are airlines ready for a summer travel boom? The industry is struggling to expand operations after two years of Covid-19 crisis management, cost-cutting and redundancies. After going into a deep freeze, passengers are coming back so quickly that airlines do not know what to do with them.

The threat of a global ‘buying strike' rises as cost-of-living hits History shows us that when consumers cut back on discretionary spending it poses a serious risk for markets, writes Rana Foroohar. With inflation at a 40-year high in America and adjusted household incomes falling at the fastest pace since the government began collecting data in 1959, this is beginning to happen, she says.

Elon Musk blazes trail for new-model investor activism Shareholder activism is on the rise. And Tesla's chief executive, a loudmouth proponent of electric cars, gas-guzzling rockets and multiple other contradictions, is its protagonist. That leaves underperforming companies vulnerable, writes Patrick Jenkins.

  • More opinion: The world's richest man seems uninterested in what Twitter needs help with the most: rethinking its business model, argues John Thornhill.

Crypto industry's Super Bowl ad blitz comes up short LeBron James and Larry David were among the star-studded cast of crypto commercials run during the American football game two months ago. Since then, trading has turned sluggish as factors such as rising interest rates and the war in Ukraine have damped investor spirit.

Workplace anxiety — and how to overcome it Feeling stressed or even fearful at work? Here are some simple techniques to help you manage it and support others from Viv Groskop, author of How to Own the Room.

Reader feedback

Last week I asked for your Netflix comments after the streaming service said it would lose 2mn subscribers this quarter. The shock announcement led to questions about the future of Netflix and its business model. Bas van Buijtenen, a reader living in Switzerland, shared these thoughts:

I believe there is worse to come. The fundamental rot set in when Netflix decided to pivot from being a distributor of other peoples content to becoming essentially a content provider, a studio. My prediction is that each of the streaming services will hit this problem: exclusive distribution of proprietary content will not be a profitable business model.

Thanks for all your comments. Keep them coming to firstft@ft.com. I will be back in your inbox tomorrow.
